episodes.title: Lansing IDMR Explains “on the Cross” Means “in the Grave”
1974 Kinley Said Theosophical Society Copied His Words
Was IDMR Textbook Really at The Ecumenical Council as Claimed?
episodes.description: The other ridiculous notion is that if Kinley’s  book was examined by the pope or his associates, and if it incriminated the pope, as Kinley claimed it did, why of all things would he bring that book to the ecumenical council? If anything they would’ve tucked that book in a file cabinet someplace. It’s very doubtful that the pope himself ever even had his hands on the book. People don’t realize that you don’t mail anything directly to the pope. IDMR sent that book to the Vatican unsolicited. The clergy weren’t sitting around waiting for this book to show up. Likely it went right into the garbage with all the rest of the random things mailed into the pope. Not saying the book wasn’t worth reading, but it’s extremely doubtful that an unsolicited book like that would even be considered to be forwarded to the pope. This is just another one of those overstated claims that Henry Kinley made. It’s unfalsifiable, we cannot prove nor disprove if that book ever even made it to the pope. What we do now is the ecumenical council was planned in 1958 years before Kinley even started to write the book. So it definitely wasn’t the reason why they called the meeting. There’s other plausible reasons why they called the meeting. Post World War II the new generation of baby boomers were threatening away from the church. By 1961 ￼ more than 90% of households had televisions. Interstate highways were being completed. Commercial airlines were available to the public. Suburbanization etc. The world was changing and the Catholic Church knew they were falling behind the trends. They knew they had to make some adjustments too try to win back the attention of it’s drifting attendances.

episodes.title: ￼The Night Henry Kinley Made Stars Fall: What You Didn’t Know
episodes.description:
The date of “March 19, 1924” was the day Henry’s son Richard died. As the legend was told Henry feeling dismayed that he had “healed others“, but couldn’t save his son. Henry went out onto the porch and questioned within himself, asking God if he was punishing him. He said he needed a sign. So Henry picked out a star and said “God if I’m called to be a minister make that star fall. “ Allegedly as he claimed that star fell. He went on to pick two more, the final third time was the biggest brightest star he could find in the sky. The legend is when that star fell. He fell out of his chair. Quite a dramatic story. But it can’t be true at all. An IDMR member might say I’m trusting the science, and that Yahweh is greater than man’s science. But this just doesn’t happen. It’s not that I lack of faith. It’s that this is a made up story.

Here’s why! Stars don’t fall ever! Shooting stars or meteorites, are not stars, but pieces of rock that made its way into our atmosphere and burns up. It’s only noticed because it’s on fire flying by at extreme velocities. When Henry was claiming to do was that he pointed at actual orbited massive stars, of which would make our son look like the size of a pea next to a basketball. The stars, like our Sun have planets, orbiting around them with moons orbiting around those planets. Henry was trying to tell his audiences that entire solar systems were somehow falling in real observable time. Fall ? Fall where? ￼Space is relative to itself. Nothing falls in space. 

This claim of his, showed  his complete lack of understanding. The unfathomable distances of stars determine that no star could be seen as falling in observable time.

episodes.description: This is one of many places you can find Henry Kinley telling his devoted audience statements like “you won’t see 2000”. Many have disputed that he didn’t mean the Gregorian calendar 2000. Here we see he’s plainly illustrating that that is exactly what he meant 2000 A.D. It’s referring to the year that just passed 25 years ago. Here in this particular transcript he’s not calling out Pentecost or the four-year error. But that the 6000 year timeframe only includes 120 Jubilees or 50 year cycles. Then in other places, he said “you’ll never see it”. Because this age will need to be cut short referring to the verse in Matthew 24:22. There’s no ambiguity and this is not open to interpretation. It’s plainly stated by H.C. Kinley that there would only be a total of 6000 years or 120 Jubilee’s, and that that would even be cut short. So the question we should ask is why are we not referring to Deuteronomy 18:22 ? But of course, realizing so many have invested their entire lifetime in a belief system centered around the IDMR ‘s teaching, the cognitive dissonance upon realizing that Henry Kinley profess something that did not come through on your mind, his divine authority. But one thing that is documented, is that Jean Dixon’s beat Henry Kinley to the punch on the JFK assassination prediction. It was commonly reported that Kinley claim to predict the assassination of John F Kennedy, 1958. Wilbur Carr disputed that claim saying it was 1957. ￼ But Jean Dixon predicted this in May 1956. episodes.title: Can We Verify H.C. Kinley’s Alleged PhD. Call Fisk University to Ask #investigativejournalism
episodes.description:
Our associate researcher called Fisk and found out that Fisk has no record of the honorary doctorate allegedly given to HCK in 1947. they have many others that were issued that year, but nothing for Henry Kinley.  Our team has sent letters to them as written requests for proof, responses were  inconclusive. ￼ Will Williams from the Oceanside ranch spoken before his class over a year ago telling a story that he personally visited Fisk University and asked for a copy of the honorary doctorate. They told them they would research it and get back to him. When he went back, they told him that they did not have it. ￼ But if they didn’t have, it may be a cat lost, ￼which was his only hope that it actually might’ve existed. ￼ But isn’t it strange that even in the aliens are history video, they did not produce a copy of the certificate? They gave no date in time in 1947 on the commencement. These are usually given at a ceremony there was no pictures of any reception or anything, instead they showed a postcard that he sent to his sister telling him about his trip to Fisk University saying that he thought the University would be of some help to the school. But there’s not even any written message related to the honorary doctorate.  

￼ So we are selves now call Fisk. ￼ I would’ve thought that many others would have been inquiring of this. ￼ Maybe they don’t, because they don’t really want to know the answer.

episodes.title: Does IDMR Prove Noah’s Ark By The Physical Body?
episodes.description:
True, scaphoid means “boat”, but none of the other 7 bones have names that mean anything to do with the Noah’s Ark story. They are merely named by their shapes. This one scaphoid is what’s called “cherry picked”, due to bias. ￼ If the 8 bones signify that there were ￼8 souls ( human beings) in the Ark, then if one bone represents the ark, then there’s only 7 passengers. The comparison to story doesn’t really work.

Oftentimes Dr. Harris in volume 3 seems to cherry pick certain correlations about the anatomy, that otherwise have no relevance to the story. Such as the wrist in the human body. There’s nothing about Noah’s ark or his family that had anything to do with your hand and your wrist your arm or anything. ￼ but somehow people are dazzled and I believe it is activated by confirmation bias.

episodes.title: IDMR ‘s Dr. Kinley, ￼Claimed to Stand on Mars Hill in the Body of Saul in A.D. 50 ?
episodes.description:
According to the history video, we are told Dr. H.C. ￼ Kinley, ￼ said that￼ he had been on top of Mars Hill, apparently from the ancient time of the apostle Paul.  ￼ 
 ￼There’s no way to prove, nor disprove a supernatural claim like this. At this time in 1971 ￼H.C. Kinley ￼would’ve been 75 years old, maybe he didn’t feel like￼ climbing up onto that hill, that’s my guess. ￼To make a claim like “I’ve been ￼ there, I’ve seen this before” is  outrageous! But I think people are already psychologically conditioned to easily except him, saying this sort of thing. 
 ￼I always had my doubts about some of these outrageous things that the founder claimed, or things that people claimed about him that were super natural like. 
 Not all things￼￼ HCK ￼set out to, were not accomplished . ￼N￼ot all predictions￼ he made, came true. I’ve examined many things to me seem to be a mistake, I don’t know how else you could justify some of the mistakes, and still claim to be the Almighty, All knowing, Omnipotent! 
 If claims like this were￼ really just him misrepresenting himself, to create an affect ? Then it’s one of the worst things anybody has ever tried to do to other people. Because it’s certainly disrupts peoples lives. ￼
 ￼ I know to the believers, I’m just lost, that’s the damage control in a cult!￼ A defector, has to be discredited, eliminated, and completely cut off from the rest of the group. ￼Our so-called brethren ￼status,￼ is only honored, if you are towing the line of the narrative, accepted by the group. ￼￼Protection of the doctrine, and/or its leader, must be done at all costs. You as an individual have no value! You are only valued as a member of the group. ￼These principles of the typical cult can be paralleled directly with IDMR ￼.

Something is deeply wrong!

episodes.description: It’d be really phenomenal if HCK was merely just a man who had a vision and revelation from Yahweh. Or let’s say the best Bible teacher whoever existed. But once he claimed to BE the Ultimate Eternal Yahweh himself , he seems to now be someone who would’ve never been capable of making mistakes. To avoid confusion, let’s refrain from trying to make this obscure. He plainly said “ I’m the one Moses went up into the mount to see….and in that state, I’m GIVING the vision..”

episodes.title: Did Founder of IDMR Say “The World Wasn’t Ready?” But Since 1928 Sacred Name Movement taught Yahweh
episodes.description: We were told H.C. Kinley knew the names all along, but said “the world wasn’t ready yet “. But the Sacred Name Movement was establishing in the late twenties, and grew exponentially in the mid 1930’s . Thousands of people were pushing the agenda for using the Sacred Names, for decades before HCK decided it was time for IDMR to transition. This raises questions.

episodes.description: The false doomsday predictions got national attention. None of those who perpetrated these predictions on the members , never apologized for derailing the lives of thousands of members, and their families.

episodes.title: False Predictions from IDMR’s leaders, destroyed lives!
episodes.description:
Correction: the 2001 international convention was in Nashville. I was there and that’s the one I mistakenly referred to as being Chicago. 

Does anyone think how bad the false predictions of the doomsday, destroyed lives? Long time leaders of IDMR such as Dr. Harris made a series of wrong predictions that misled members to make life altering decisions causing terrible consequences. I attended these lectures for years. But was always amazed that after these predictions failed, so many glossed over the tragedies of members being dissuaded from making responsible decisions, and plans for their futures. Nobody talks about it and it’s the elephant in every room that these lectures are given.

episodes.title: IDMR’s Dr. Harris made a series of wrong predictions! 😳😨
episodes.description: Dr. Robert Harris, the international dean of the IDMR made a series of blatant wrong predictions! ￼ He endorsed a false calculation and phony prediction of 1996, ￼ then he changed it to 2007, claiming that the seven would be symbolic of the Sabbath. Then he later changed the year for the end of the world, to be 2010..saying that it would be a Jubilee (50 years) from 1960. ￼ Because 1960 was a date that the founder Henry C. Kinley said was the chronological end,￼ and that we are now in a “ grace period” .. this said grace period was ￼a term also used by a cult known as Branhamism, a cult founded by Joseph Branham, who predicted that 1977 would be the end of the word, before he himself died in 1965. After the failed prediction, his followers decided that Joseph had went on into heaven to prepare a place for them, and that they were in a “grace period”.. ￼ his followers instead became stronger and said, “..isn’t it great that we now have a chance to get it right!” ￼ I have heard the exact same words spoken by members of the IDMR, when they speak of the “ grace period “. ￼ you would think that after Dr. Harris had made so many blatant wrong predictions, that his followers would have diminished, or quit altogether, but that’s not the case! ￼ They continued on like there wasn’t anything wrong! It’s the elephant in the rooms that nobody admits to. Instead, they make excuses, and blame themselves for not really understanding what he actually meant! This is all “Cult psychology 101.”

episodes.title: IDMR’s cult of “Dr. Harris, was Dr. Kinley”,  & Dr. Harris’s false predictions.
episodes.description: It’s notable that the video we are critiquing, banners “Dr. Henry C. Kinley: God in a body,” but most frames, and the featured frame, is of Dr. Robert Harris. This is because this particular camp believes Robert Harris is actually Henry C. Kinley. That’s why their catch phrase is: “Dr. Kinley hasn’t gone anywhere .” this is what’s called in cult psychology, “ a thought terminating cliché ”, but with an obscure meaning. It’s a toxic concept, that imposes that “Henry C. Kinley” is some sort of “Avatar “ , meaning a released soul and or deity that was incarnate on Earth in a new body. That body being “Dr. Robert Harris “. Who has since passed. It’s a spooky concept, and keeps the focus on a particular physical man. Instead of the universal spiritual aspect. One recorded testimony from an attendee at the New Orleans branch, said the Dean of that school, claimed in 1994, to see and meet Dr. Kinley in a hotel room, and hugged him , and as he looked again realized it was Dr. Robert Harris he was hugging. So to him was a transformation of one man into another… Dr. Henry C. Kinley had passed in 1976. So this alleged experience was 18 years after. These sorts of toxic concepts, promote cognitive dissonance. On top of this, Robert Harris made a series of wrong end of the world predictions. This was extremely reckless and damaging to the lives of the IDMR members. A man in the top position of the institution, dissuading, and derailing the lives of its members!

episodes.title: IDMR’s Aims Taken From the Theosophical Society ..
episodes.description: My purpose of this video is not necessarily to discredit, or invalidate the founder, nor his explanations. ￼ But to be aware that some of the material was previously known, or are used by previous authors. It seems odd that he seen so much from Yahweh, but he still needed to copy from others..￼ I hope to open discussion, to gain knowledge￼, and background pertaining to things like this.
